February 1965

The linguistics major is first approved for Columbia College students.

October 1965

The linguistics department decides to postpone the availability of the major until “given the appropriate personnel and budget.”

Dean Thomas S. Colahan

Between 1965 and 1971, four faculty depart from the Graduate School for Arts and Sciences’ linguistics department.

February 1971

November 1971

An inter-faculty committee on linguistics is formed to study and resolve the understaffing issues in GSAS’ linguistics department.

February 1972

The committee’s suggestions are approved by George K. Fraenkel, the dean of GSAS. They include a significant reduction in the linguistics department’s funding in the face of a University budget crisis.

1981

Columbia College eliminates its linguistics department.

1983

The Columbia major is discontinued. Barnard is now the only school that offers an undergraduate linguistics program.

October 1984

Citing “limited resources,” Barnard's Faculty Planning Committee (FPC), a group of faculty members charged with studying the college’s academic affairs, decides to eliminate the tenure-track position of Robert May, a former assistant professor in linguistics. He teaches four linguistics courses at Columbia and Barnard.

February 1985

TK submits a proposal to disband Barnard's Department of Linguistics.

“The fate of [Barnard’s] linguistics department will affect more than just Barnard.”

 

—Barnard Dean of Faculty Charles Olton

Barnard teaches four of the eight required courses for an advanced degree from the Graduate School for Arts and Sciences (GSAS). The department also runs a joint BA/MA program with Teachers College.

February 28, 1986

Regarding the FPC’s elimination of May’s role, Spectator writes in a staff editorial,

In an effort to save the sum of an assistant professor's salary and a few office-support costs, the school has undermined its academic and intellectual integrity.
